repnme.cdata!: India - Second Tamil Nadu Urban Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Tamil Nadu Urban Development
            Project had the following ratings: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The
            experience under this project illustrated some of the
            limitations of partial private ownership to improve
            municipal finances. Decentralization is a process that is
            prone to reversals and decelerations. The State level
            reforms expected at the beginning of the project did not
            materialize, but the project still achieved considerable
            successes. The ISP component would most likely have been
            handled much better in a stand-alone project or as part of
            an operation involving more closely related issues. It has
            been noted by an external reviewer that the innovative
            transactions pioneered by the Tamil Nadu Urban Development
            Fund (TNUDF) have not been succeeded by the creation of a
            framework that would permit a market for this type of
            transaction. In implementing this operation, the TNUDF was
            stretched to meet the Bank's very detailed project
            finance model, including economic and financial analysis,
            safeguard and fiduciary rules while operating within a
            dynamic financial market servicing a large number of Urban
            Local Bodies ULBs.

repnme.cdata!: India - Second Tamil Nadu Urban Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Tamil Nadu Urban Development
            Project will improve urban infrastructure services in a
            sustainable manner, and will build the institutional and
            financial capacities of the urban local bodies (ULBs). The
            project components include: 1) institutional development, to
            enhance the capacity building of ULBs and the Department of
            Municipal Administration and Water Supply (DMAWS). This
            component also include the provision of technical assistance
            to the Tamil Nadu Urban Development Fund (TNUDF) and ULBs
            regarding bond issuance, and to ULBs for project preparation
            and implementation; 2) urban investments, which will provide
            a line of credit through the TNUDF, as well as funds for an
            integrated sanitation program for the targeted urban poor.
            It is expected that the project will bring economic, health,
            and environmental benefits to the Tamil Nadu's urban
            population, including to its low-income segment population,
            through improvements in the quality, quantity, and
            sustainability of urban services.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Second Tamil Nadu Urban Development
            Project : social and environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Tamil Nadu Urban Infrastructure Financial Services
            Project, which mobilizes and channels resources from capital
            markets into high priority infrastructure investments. Loss
            of land, structures (houses and commercial property), labor
            and trade, access to commonly enjoyed civic amenities and
            services, and standing crops and trees will be offset by the
            following options offered: equivalent land or cash
            compensation at replacement or market value; reasonable
            transition allowance; employment in reconstructed enterprise
            or package for re-employment or starting a business; and
            restoration or replacement of amenities. Major environmental
            impacts are anticipated with water treatment plant projects
            and river intake works, and regarding sewerage collection
            and treatment to maintain water quality. Laws have been
            enacted to control water pollution, such as the requirement
            to obtain consent to discharge effluent and to pay consent
            fees to the state pollution control board for projects
            causing water pollution. Projects having only moderate
            environmental issues will have these impacts mitigated by
            the generic design guidelines laid down by the agency set up
            to manage the project (TNUIFSL).
